title: Charge of 1 µC, -2 µC, 1 µC, -2 µC is placed at A, B, C and D respectively of a square of side 1.234 cm. What is the electric field intensity at the center of the square? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let us imagine a square of a side length L = 1.234 cm. The side length has been given up to three decimal places. This raises an intuition that this may not be a piece of useful information. Now look at the charges- they have been placed at the corners of square say ABCD. At A and C, the charge is equal and is q1= 1 microcoulomb. they are diagonally opposite and equidistant from the center (O)which is at the crossing point of diagonals. Note that in a square the diagonals cross through the center and divide themselves in half-length. so if one places a unit positive charge at center O to get the forces by charges at A and C, then charge q1 at A will push it towards C and C-charge q1 will push it towards A. Using coulombs law of electrostatics F due to A = k.q1 /(L/Sqrt(2))^2 this will act along OC as AO = (1/2) sqrt( L*2 + L^2) = L/Sqrt(2) ,where the rt angle triangle rule is used Force F due to C-charge will be of the same value but acting along OA ( as the charge and distance OC is the same as OA. this pair of charges will produce zero net force as the forces are equal and opposite. If one does a similar calculation of forces at O due to pair of charges at B and D. q2 = -2 micro-coulombs, one will find that B is pulling the unit positive charge along OB and D is pulling along OD but the distances being equal( L/Sqrt(2))and charges being the same the pulling force will cancel each other. Therefore the net force at center O will be zero.

Two equal charges are placed on opposite vertices AA and CC of a square. At the centre of the square the electric field intensities of these two charges are equal and opposite and hence cancel each other. Two other equal charges are placed on the other opposite vertices BB and DD of the same square. At the centre of the square the electric field intensities of these two charges are equal and opposite and hence cancel each other. ⇒⇒ At the centre of the square the net electric field intensity is zero.
